articles.headline: Rental Building’s Good Karma Nurtures Success
articles.snippet: Over the years, one building in Palo Alto, Calif., has been home to some of Silicon Valley’s most successful start-ups.
articles.abstract: Over the years, one building in Palo Alto, Calif., has been home to some of Silicon Valley’s most successful start-ups.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 13 — The building at 165 University Avenue here has been so good to the Amidi family that Saeed Amidi says it is blessed with good karma. There are some high-technology entrepreneurs who would agree.

articles.headline: Waiting for the Fed, and Hoping
articles.snippet: Corporate pessimism seems to be growing. Would a Fed rate cut help?
articles.abstract: Corporate pessimism seems to be growing. Would a Fed rate cut help?
articles.lead_paragraph: That there is a financial crisis is clear. What is not so clear is whether the medicine in Dr. Ben Bernanke’s bag can do much good.

articles.headline: Warning Signs and Defining Economic Moments
articles.snippet: There are signs that consumers are beginning to be more cautious as a result of the turmoil in the credit markets.
articles.abstract: There are signs that consumers are beginning to be more cautious as a result of the turmoil in the credit markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Annie Cox is unsure if the economy is headed south — a question on the minds of many on Wall Street and Main Street these days — she keeps an eye on the orders for beverages at the diner she runs in Oklahoma City.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Sunni Sheik Who Backed U.S. in Iraq Is Killed
articles.snippet: A high-profile sheik who collaborated with the U.S. military in the fight against jihadist militants was killed in a bomb attack.
articles.abstract: A high-profile sheik who collaborated with the U.S. military in the fight against jihadist militants was killed in a bomb attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Sept. 13 — A high-profile Sunni Arab sheik who collaborated with the American military in the fight against jihadist militants in western Iraq was killed in a bomb attack on Thursday near his desert compound. The attack appeared to be a precisely planned assassination meant to undermine one of the Bush administration’s trumpeted achievements in the war.

articles.headline: U.A.W. Said to Pick G.M. for Contract Negotiations
articles.snippet: The choice may signal the union’s willingness to bargain on a health care trust as the current contract with automakers is set to expire Friday night.
articles.abstract: The choice may signal the union’s willingness to bargain on a health care trust as the current contract with automakers is set to expire Friday night.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Sept. 13 — The United Automobile Workers union has chosen General Motors as its lead company in negotiations on contracts that are set to expire at midnight on Friday, people with knowledge of the union’s decision said on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Mary M. Chapman

articles.headline: San Francisco to Offer Care for Uninsured Adults
articles.snippet: An initiative, known as Healthy San Francisco, is the first effort by a locality to guarantee care to all of its uninsured.
articles.abstract: An initiative, known as Healthy San Francisco, is the first effort by a locality to guarantee care to all of its uninsured.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Since contracting polio at age 2, Yin Ling Ho has lived with pain for most of her 52 years. After she immigrated here from Hong Kong last year, the soreness in her back and joints proved too debilitating for her to work.

articles.headline: A Dropout Problem for Colleges
articles.snippet: The departure from Harvard this week of Mohamed A. El-Erian highlights the difficulties that universities face in retaining endowment chiefs.
articles.abstract: The departure from Harvard this week of Mohamed A. El-Erian highlights the difficulties that universities face in retaining endowment chiefs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Beatles insisted that money can’t buy you love. Apparently it can do a lot of other things, like lure top-flight talent from one high-profile, well-paying job to another high-profile, better-paying job.

articles.headline: For Fed, a Question of Whom to Rescue, and When to Dive In
articles.snippet: Next week’s meeting of the Fed’s policy makers is likely to focus on how much to cut rates and may mark a defining moment for the Ben S. Bernanke, the Fed chairman.
articles.abstract: Next week’s meeting of the Fed’s policy makers is likely to focus on how much to cut rates and may mark a defining moment for the Ben S. Bernanke, the Fed chairman.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 — When policy makers at the Federal Reserve meet to set interest rates on Tuesday, their debate is likely to be less about whether to reduce rates than about how much.
